reaction.ptxt: Hydrogen does not react with water, acids or bases.
reaction.title: Reactions with oxygen
reaction.ptxt: A mixture of hydrogen gas and air will not react unless ignited with a spark or flame, in this case the result is a fire or explosion whose only product is water.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Hydrogen gas reacts with fluorine to produced hydrogen(I) fluoride.

Helium is chemically unreactive under all normal conditions due to its valence of zero. It is an electrical insulator unless ionized. As with the other noble gases, helium has metastable energy levels that allow it to remain ionized in an electrical discharge with a voltage below its ionization potential. Helium can form unstable compounds with tungsten, iodine, fluorine, sulfur and phosphorus when it is subjected to an electric glow discharge, through electron bombardment or is otherwise a plasma. HeNe, HgHe10, WHe2 and the molecular ions He2+, He2++, HeH+, and HeD+ have been created this way. This technique has also allowed the production of the neutral molecule He2, which has a large number of band systems, and HgHe, which is apparently only held together by polarization forces. Theoretically, other compounds, like helium fluorohydride (HHeF), may also be possible.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Lithium metals reacts slowly with water to form a colourless solution of lithium hydroxide (LiOH) and hydrogen gas, H2. The resulting solution is basic because of the dissolved hydroxide. The reaction is exothermic, but the reaction is slower than that of sodium.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: When lithium is burned in air, the main product is the white oxide lithium oxide, Li2O. Some lithium peroxide, Li2O2, also white, is also produced.
Lithium reacts with nitrogen, N2, to form lithium nitride, Li3N. No other Gruop 1 element does anything similar, but the group 2 metal magnesium forms a similar nitride.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Lithium metal reacts vigorously with all the halogens to form lithium halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Lithium metal dissolves readily in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the aquated Li(I) ion together with hydrogen gas, H2.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Lithium metals reacts slowly with water to form a colourless solution of basic lithium hydroxide (LiOH) and hydrogen gas (H2). The reaction continues even when the solution becomes basic. The resulting solution is basic because of the dissolved hydroxide. The reaction is exothermic, but the reaction is slower than that of sodium. As the reaction continues, the concentration of the hydroxide increases.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Beryllium will not react with water (or steam) even if heated.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: The surface of beryllium metal is covered with a thin layer of oxide that helps protect the metal from attack by air. It does not oxidize in air even at 600°ree;C. Powdered beryllium metal does burn in air to give a mixture of white beryllium oxide, BeO, and beryllium nitride, Be3N2.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Beryllium metal reacts chlorine, Cl2, or bromine, Br2, to form the beryllium dihalides; beryllium(II) chloride, BeCl2, and beryllium(II) bromide, BeBr2, respectively.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: The surface of beryllium metal is covered with a thin layer of oxide that helps protect the metal from attack by acids, but powdered beryllium metal dissolves readily in dilute acids such as sulphuric acid, hydrochloric acid, or nitric acid to form solutions containing the aquated Be(II) ion together with hydrogen gas, H2.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Beryllium metal dissolves readily in dilute aquesous base solutions such as sodium hydroxide, NaOH, to form Be(II) complexes together with hydrogen gas, H2.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Boron will not react with water under normal conditions.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: At higher temperatures, boron does burn in air to form boron(III) oxide, B2O3.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Boron reacts vigorously with fluorine, chlorine, and bromine to form boron(III) trihalides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Crystalline boron does not react with boiling hydrochloric acid (HCl) or boiling hydrofluoric acid (HF). Powdered boron oxidizes slowly when treated with concentrated nitric acid, HNO3.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Carbon, either as graphite or diamond does not react with water under normal conditions. Under more forceful conditions, the reaction becomes important. In industry, water is blown through hot coke. The resulting gas is called water gas and is a mixture of hydrogen (H2, 50%), carbon monoxide (CO, 40%), carbon dioxide (CO2, 5%), nitrogen and methane (N2 + CH4, 5%). It is an important feedstock gas for the chemical industry.
This reaction is endothermic which means that the coke cools down during the reaction. To counteract this, the steam flow is replaced by air to reheat the coke allowing further reaction.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Carbon, as graphite, burns in oxygen to form gaseous carbon(IV) dioxide. Carbon, as diamond, also burns in air when heated to 600-800°ree;C to also form carbon(IV) oxide.
When the air or oxygen is restricted then incomplete combustion to carbon monoxide (CO) occurs.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Graphite reacts with fluorine (but none of the other halogens) at high temperatures to make a mixture of carbon tetrafluoride, CF4, together with some C2F6 and C5F12.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Graphite reacts with hot concentrated nitric acid to form mellitic acid, C6(CO2H)6.
Under normal conditions nitrogen will not react with air, water, halogens, acids or bases.
Oxygen does not react with acids or bases under normal conditions.
reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Oxygen will not react with water.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Oxygen gas does not react with itself or nitrogen under normal conditions. However the effect of ultraviolet light upon oxygen gas is to form the blue gas ozone, O3.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Irradiation of a low pressure mixture of oxygen and fluorine gases will produce dioxygen difluoride.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Fluorine will react with water to produce oxygen and ozone.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Fluorine is not reactive towards oxygen or nitrogen. If will react with moisture in the air to produce oxygen, see above.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Fluorine reacts with chlorine at 225°ree;C to form the interhalogen species ClF. The trifluoride chlorine(III) fluoride is also formed and the reaction does not go to completion.
Under more forcing conditions, excess fluorine reacts with chlorine at 350°ree;C and 225 atmospheres pressure to form the interhalogen species ClF5.

Fluorine reacts with bromine in the gas phase to form the interhalogen species BrF. The product is difficult to obtain pure since BrF disproportionates at toom temperature to form bromine, Br2, and BrF3 and BrF5.
Under more forcing conditions, excess fluorine reacts with bromine at 150°ree;C to form the interhalogen species BrF5.

Fluorine reacts with iodine at about -45°ree;C in CCl3F solvent to form the interhalogen species IF. The product is dificult to obtain pure since IF disproportionates at toom temperature to form iodine, I2, and IF5.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: With dilute acids, fluorine's reaction is probaly dominated by that with water, which produces oxygen and ozone.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Fluorine reacts with dilute aqueous hydroxide solutions to form oxygen(II) fluoride.
Under normal conditions neon will not react with air, water, halogens, acids or bases.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Sodium metal reacts rapidly with water to form a colourless solution of sodium hydroxide and hydrogen gas. The is an exothermic reaction, the sodium metal may well become so hot that it catches fire and burns with a characteristic orange colour. The reaction is slower than that of potassium but faster than that of lithium.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: The shiny surface of sodium soons becomes dull due to the reaction of air and moisture.
When sodium is burnt in air the result is white sodium peroxide together with some white sodium oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Sodium reacts vigorously with all halogens to form sodium halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Sodium readily dissolves in dilute sulphuric acid to form a solution containing the Na(I) ion and hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Sodium metal reacts rapidly with water to form a colourless solution of sodium hydroxide and hydrogen gas. The is an exothermic reaction, the sodium metal may well become so hot that it catches fire and burns with a characteristic orange colour. The reaction is slower than that of potassium but faster than that of lithium.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Although magnesium does not react with water to any significant extent it does react with steam to yield magnesium oxide, or magnesium hydroxide with excess steam, and hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: A thin layer of oxide helps to protect magnesium from attack by air. However, once ignited magnesium burns in air with its characteristic intensely bright white flame. This yields magnesium oxide and magnesium trioxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Magnesium will react with chlorine and bromine to form magnesium(II) dihalides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Magnesium will dissolve readily in dilute sulphuric acid, as will as other acids, to form solutions containing the Mg(II) ion and hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Magnesium appears not to react with dilute alkalis.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: A thin layer of oxide prevents aluminium being attack by water.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: A thin layer of oxide prevents aluminium being attack by air. Aluminium will burn in oxygen with a brillian white flame to form aluminium trixode.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Aluminium reacts vigorously with all halogens to form aluminium halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Aluminium dissolves readily in dilute suphuric acid for form solutions containing the Al(III) ion and hydroden gas.
The reaction with dilute hydrochloric acid also yield the same Al(III) ion and hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Aluminium dissolves in sodium hydroxide to yield hydrogen gas and aluminates of the form [Al(OH)4]-.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: A surface layer of oxide makes silicon unreactive to water and steam.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Due to a thin layer of oxide on a sample of silicon it will not react with oxygen below temperatures of 900°ree;C, above this the reaction with oxygen gives silicon dioxide.
At temperatures above 1400°ree;C the silicon will react with nitrogen to give silicon nitrides.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Silicon reacts vigorously with all the halogens to form tetrahalides, the reaction with fluorine takes place at room temperature, the others require heating over 300°ree;C.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Under normal conditions silicon does not react with most acids, but is dissolved by hydrofluoric acid.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Silicon is attacked by bases such as aqueous sodium hydroxide to give silicates.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: White phosphorus glows in the dark when exposed to damp air in a process known as chemiluminescence.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: White phosphorus must be handled with great care. It spontanteously ignites in air at about room temperature to form "phosphorus pentoxide" - actually tetraphosphorus decaoxide, P4O10.
Under careful control (75% O2, 25% N2, 50°ree;C, 90 mm Hg), a mixture is formed, one of the products within which is "phosphorus trioxide" - actually tetraphosphorus hexaoxide, P4O6.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: White phosphorus, P4, reacts vigorously with all the halogens at room temeperature to form phosphorus(III) trihalides.
White phosphorus reacts with iodine in carbon disulphide (CS2) to form phosphorus(II) iodide. The same compound is formed in the reaction between red phosphorus and iodine at 180°ree;C.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Phosphorus does not react with dilute non-oxidizing acids.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Sulfur will not react with water under standard conditions.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Sulfur burns in air to form sulfur(IV) dioxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Sulfur reacts with fluorine and burns to form sulfur(VI) hexafluoride.
Molten sulfur will react with chlorine to form disulfur dichloride.
With excess chlorine and in the presence of a catalyst it is possible to make a mixture containing and equilibrium of sulfur(II) chloride and disulfur dichloride.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Sulphur does not react with dilute non-oxidizing acids.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Sulfur reacts with hot aqueous potassium hydroxide to form sulfide and thiosulfate species.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Chlorine reacts with water to produce hypochlorite, OCl-. The pH of the solution determines the position of the equilibrium.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Chlorine is not reactive towards nitrogen or oxygen.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Fluorine reacts with chlorine at 225°ree;C to form the interhalogen species ClF. The trifluoride chlorine(III) fluoride is also formed if the reaction does not go to completion.
Under more forcing conditions, excess fluorine reacts with chlorine at 350°ree;C and 225 atmospheres pressure to form the interhalogen species ClF5.
Chlorine, reacts with bromine in the gas phase to form the unstable interhalogen species bromine(I) chloride, ClBr.
Chlorine reacts with iodine at room temperature to form the interhalogen species iodine(I) chloride, ClI.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Chlorine reacts with hot aqueous alkali to produce chlorate, ClO3-. Only one sixth of the total chlorine is converted in this reaction.
Under normal conditions argon will not react with air, water, halogens, acids or bases.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Potassium reacts very rapidly with water to form a colourless solution of potassium hydroxide and hydrogen gas. The resulting solution is basic because of the dissolved hydroxide. This reaction is exothermic. Early in the reaction, the potassium becomes so hot that it catches fire and burns with a characteristic pale lilac colour.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Potassium tarnishes quickly in air due to a reaction of oxygen and moisture. If potassium is burned in air, the result is mainly formation of orange potassium superoxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Potassium metal reacts vigorously with all the halogens to form potassium(I) halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Potassium dissolves readily in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the aquated K(I) ion together with hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Potassium reacts very rapidly with water to form a colourless solution of potassium hydroxide and hydrogen gas. The resulting solution is basic because of the dissolved hydroxide. This reaction is exothermic. Early in the reaction, the potassium becomes so hot that it catches fire and burns with a characteristic pale lilac colour.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Calcium reacts slowly with water to form calcium hydroxide and hydrogen gas. The calcium metal sinks in water and after an hour or so bubbles of hydrogen are evident, stuck to the surface of the metal.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: The surface of calcium metal is covered with a thin layer of oxide that helps protect the metal from attack by air, but to a lesser extent than the corresponding layer in magnesium. Once ignited, calcium burns in air to give a mixture of white calcium oxide and calcium nitride.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Calcium is very reactive towards the halogens fluorine, chlorine, bromine and iodine, and burns to form calcium(II) dihalides.
The reactions with bromine and iodine require heat to enable the formation of the products.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Calcium metal dissolves readily in dilute or concentrated hydrochloric acid to form solutions containing the aquated Ca(II) ion together with hydrogen gas.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: When heated or finely divided scandium will dissolve in water to form solutions containing the aquated Sc(III) and hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Scandium tarnishes in air and burns readily to form scandium(III) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Scandium is very reactive towards all of the halogens, to produce trihalides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Scandium readily dissolves in dilute hydrochloric acid to form solutions containing the aquated Sc(III) ion together with hydrogen gas.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Titanium is coated with a thin oxide layer that under normal circumstances renders inert in air. However, titanium will react with steam to form titanium(IV) oxide and hydrogen.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Titanium is coated with a thin oxide layer that under normal circumstances renders inert in air. However, once titanium starts to burn in air it burns with a bright white flame to form titanium oxide and titanium nitride. It will burn in pure nitrogen to form titanium nitride.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Titanium does react with the halogens upon warming to form titanium(IV) halides. The reaction with fluorine requires heating to 200°ree;C.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Dilute aqueous hydrofluoric acid reacts with titanium to form the complex anion [TiF6]3- together with hydrogen.
Titanium metal does not react with mineral acids at ambient temperature but does react with hot hydrochloric acic to form titanium(III) complexes.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Titanium does not appear to react wih alkalis under normal conditions, even when hot.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: The surface of vanadium metal is protected by an oxide layer and does not reacts with water under normal conditions.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Vanadium metal reacts with excess oxygen upon heating to form vanadium(V) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Vanadium reacts with fluorine upon warming to form vanadium(V) fluoride.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Vanadium metal is resistant to attack by molten alkalis.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Chromium metal does not react with water at room temperature.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: hromium metal does not react with air or oxygen at room temperature.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Chromium reacts directly with fluorine at 400°ree;C and 200-300 atmospheres to form chromium(VI) fluoride.
Under less extreme conditions, chromium(V) fluoride is formed.
Under milder conditions still, chromium metal reacts with the halogens to form chromium(III) trihalides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Chromium metal dissolves in dilute hydrochloric acid to form solutions containing the aquated Cr(II) ion together with hydrogen gas.
Similar results are seen for sulphuric acid but pure samples of chromium may be resistant to attack. Chromium metal does not react with nitric acid.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Manganese does not react with water under normal conditions
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: When finely divided, manganese metal burns in air. It burns in oxygen to form the oxide Mn3O4 and in nitrogen to form the nitride Mn3N2.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Manganese burns in chlorine to form manganese(II) chloride.
Manganese burns in bromine to form manganese(II) bromide.
Manganese burns in iodine to form manganese(II) iodide.
The corresponding reaction between the metal and fluorine yields the manganese(II) fluoride and manganese(III) fluoride.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Manganese metal dissolves readily in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the aquated Mn(II) ion together with hydrogen gas.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Air-free water has little effect upon iron metal. However, iron metal reacts in moist air by oxidation to give a hydrated iron oxide. This does not protect the iron surface to further reaction since it flakes off, exposing more iron metal to oxidation. This process is called rusting!
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Iron metal reacts in moist air by oxidation to give a hydrated iron oxide. This does not protect the iron surface to further reaction since it flakes off, exposing more iron metal to oxidation. This process is called rusting. Finely divided iron powder is pyrophoric, making it a fire risk.
On heating with oxygen the result is formation of the iron oxides Fe2O3 and Fe3O4.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Iron reacts with excess of fluorine, chlorine and bromine to form Fe(III) halides.

This reaction is not very successful for iodine because of thermodynamic problems. The iron(III) is too oxidizing and the iodide is too reducing. The direct reaction between iron and iodine can be used to prepare iron (II) iodide.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Iron metal dissolves readily in dilute sulphuric acid in the absence of oxygen to form solutions containing the aquated Fe(II) ion together with hydrogen gas.
If oxygen is present, some of the Fe(II) oxidizes to Fe(III).
The strongly oxidizing concentrated nitric acid, HNO3, reacts on th surface of iron and passivates the surface.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Water has little or no effect on cobalt. However, the reaction of red-hot cobalt and steam produces cobalt(II) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Cobalt is not very reactive with air. Cobalt will not react directly with nitrogen. Heating will produce cobalt oxide.
Heating above 900°ree;C will result in cobalt(II) oxide being formed.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Cobalt reacts with chlorine, bromine and iodine to form cobalt dihalides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Cobalt metal dissolves in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the Co(II) ion and hydrogen gas.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Nickel does not react with water under normal conditions.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Nickel does not react with air under ambient conditions. Finely divided nickel metal reacts readily with air and in this form may be pyrophoric. At higher temperatures, the reaction between nickel metal and oxygen appears not to proceed to completion but gives some nickel(II) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Nickel does react with fluorine gas but only slowly which makes nickel an important metal for containers of fluorine.
Nickel reacts with chlorine, bromine and iodine to form nickel(II) dihalides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Nickel metal dissolves slowly in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the aquated Ni(II) ion together with hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Nickel does not react with aquaous sodium hydroxide.

reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Copper metal is stable in air under normal conditions. When red hot, copper metal and oxygen react to form Cu2O.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Copper reacts with fluorine, chlorine and bromine to form copper(II) dihalides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Copper metal dissolves in hot concentrated sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the aquated Cu(II) ion together with hydrogen gas.
Copper metal also dissolves in dilute or concentrated nitric acid.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Zinc does not react with water.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Zinc tarnishes in moist air. Zinc metal burns in air to form the white zinc(II) oxide, a material that turns yellow on prolonged heating.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Zinc reacts with bromine and iodine to form zinc(II) dihalides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Zinc dissolves slowly in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the aquated Zn(II) ion together with hydrogen gas.
The reactions of zinc with oxidizing acids such as nitric acid, HNO3, are complex and depend upon precise conditions.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Zinc dissolves in aqueous alkalis such as potassium hydroxide, KOH, to form zincates such as [Zn(OH)4]2- (although other species are also present).

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: The thin oxide layer renders germanium more or less inert to water.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: The surface of lumps of germanium is protected by a very thin layer of germanium dioxide. At red heat, germanium reacts with oxygen in air to from germanium dioxide.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Arsenic does not react with water in the absence of air under normal conditions.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Arsenic is stable in dry air, but the surface oxidizes slowly in moist air to give a bronze tarnish and finally a black covering. When heated in air, arsenic ignites "arsenic trioxide" - actually tetra-arsenic hexaoxide, As4O6. This is accompanied by phosphorescence under some conditions. When heated in oxygen, arsenic ignites to form "arsenic pentoxide" - actually tetra-arsenic decaoxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Arsenic reacts with fluorine to form the gas arsenic(V) fluoride.
Arsenic reacts under controlled conditions with the halogens fluorine, chlorine, bromine and iodine to form arsenic(III) trihalides.

reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Selenium burns in air to form the selenium(IV) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Selenium reacts with fluorine and burns to form the selenium(VI) fluoride.
Selenium (preferably suspended in CS2) reacts with chlorine and bromine to form diselenium dichloride and diselenium dibromide, respectively.

When carefully done, selenium reacts with fluorine at 0°ree;C to form the selenium(IV) fluoride. Selenium also reacts under controlled conditions with the other halogens chlorine, bromine, and iodine, to form selenium(IV) tetrahalides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Selenium does not react with dilute non-oxidizing acids.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Bromine reacts with water to produce hypobromite, OBr-. The pH of the solution determines the position of the equilibrium.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Bromine is not reactive towards oxygen or nitrogen but it will react ozone at -78°ree;C to form the unstable compound bromine(IV) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Bromine reacts with chlorine in the gas phase to form the interhalogen species BrF. The product is difficult to obtain pure since BrF disproportionates at room temperature to form bromine, Br2, and BrF3 and BrF5.
Under more forceful conditions, excess fluorine reacts with bromine at 150°ree;C to form the interhalogen species BrF5.
Chlorine reacts with bromine in the gas phase to form the unstable interhalogen species bromine(I) chloride, ClBr.
Bromine reacts with iodine at room temperature to form the interhalogen species bromine(I) iodide, BrI.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Bromine reacts with hot aqueous alkali to produce bromate. Only one sixth of the total bromine is converted in this reaction.

reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Kryton does not react with air.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: When a mixture of krypton and fluorine, is cooled to -196°ree;C (the boiling point of nitrogen) and zapped with an electric discharge or X-rays, the result is formation of the difluoride krypton(II) fluoride. This compound decomposes on warming to room temperature.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Krypton does not react with any acids.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Krypton does not react with any bases.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Rubidium metal reacts very rapidly with water to form a colourless solution of rubidium hydroxide (RbOH) and hydrogen gas (H2). The reaction is very exothermic. The resulting solution is basic because of the dissolved hydroxide. The reaction is so fast that if the reaction is carried out in a glass vessel, the glass container may well shatter. The reaction is slower than that of caesium (below rubidium in the periodic table), but faster than that of potassium (above rubidium in the periodic table).
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Rubidium is very soft and easily cut, the resulting surface is bright and shiny. However, this surface soon tarnishes because of reaction with oxygen and moisture from the air. If rubidium is burned in air, the result is mainly formation of dark brown rubidium superoxide, RbO2.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Rubidium metal reacts vigorously with all the halogens to form rubidium(I) halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Rubidium metal dissolves readily in dilute sulphuric acid (H2SO4) to form solutions containing the Rb(I) ion together with hydrogen gas, H2.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Rubidium metal reacts very rapidly with water to form a colourless basic solution of rubidium hydroxide (RbOH) and hydrogen gas (H2). The reaction continues even when the solution becomes basic. The resulting solution is basic because of the dissolved hydroxide. As the reaction proceeds, the concentration of base increases. The reaction is very exothermic. The reaction is so fast that if the reaction is carried out in a glass vessel, the glass container may well shatter! The reaction is slower than that of caesium (below rubidium in the periodic table), but faster than that of potassium (above rubidium in the periodic table).

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Strontium reacts slowly with water. to form strontium hydroxide, Sr(OH)2 and hydrogen gas. The strontium metal sinks in water and after a short while bubbles of hydrogen are evident, stuck to the surface of the metal.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Strontium is a silvery white metal. The surface of strontium metal is covered with a thin layer of oxide that helps protect the metal from attack by air, but to a lesser extent than the corresponding layer in magnesium. Once ignited, strontium metal burns in air to give a mixture of white strontium oxide and strontium nitride.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Strontium is very reactive towards chlorine, bromine and iodine and burns to form strontium(II) dihalides. The reaction with bromine takes place at about 400°ree;C and that with iodine at a dull red heat.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Strontium dissolves readily in dilute or concentrated hydrochloric acid to form solutions containing the aquated Sr(II) ion together with hydrogen gas.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: When finely divided, or heated, yttrium metal dissolves in water to form solutions containing the aquated Y(III) ion together with hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Yttrium tarnishes slowly in air and burns readily to form yttrium (III) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Yttrium is very reactive towards the halogens and burns to form yttrium(III) trihalides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Yttrium dissolves readily in dilute hydrochloric acid to form solutions containing the aquated Y(III) ion together with hydrogen gas.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Zirconium does not react with water under normal conditions.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Zirconium is coated with an oxide layer that usually renders it inactive. However zirconium does burn in air if provoked to form zirconium(IV) oxide, ZrO2.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Zirconium does react with the halogens, upon warming, to form zirconium(IV) halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Zirconium metal is coated with an oxide layer that usually renders it inactive. Most cold mineral acids have little effect. Zirconium does dissolve in hydrofluoric acid, HF, presumably to form fluoro complexes.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Zirconium does not appear to react wih alkalis under normal conditions, even when hot.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Niobium does not react with air under normal conditions as surface is protected by a thin oxide layer.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Niobium does not react with air under normal conditions as surface is protected by a thin oxide layer.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Niobium does react with the halogens upon warming to form niobium(V) halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Niobium appears not to be attacked by many acids at room temperature but does dissolve in hydrofluoric acid, HF, or in a mixture of HF and nitric acid, HNO3.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Niobium metal is largely resistant to attack by molten alkali but will dissolve slowly.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: At room temperate molybdenum will not react with water.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Molybdenum will not react with air or oxygen or normal temperatures, at high temperatures molybdenum(VI) trioxide is formed.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: At room temperatures molybdenum will react with fluorine to form molybdenum(VI) fluoride.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Technetium does not react with water under normal conditions.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Technetium tarnishes only very slowly in moist air. In practice, technetium is often supplied as a powder or as a sponge, and in this form it is much more reactive. When heated with oxygen the result is technetium (VII) oxide, (techentium heptoxide, Tc2O7).
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: technetium is often supplied as a powder or as a sponge, and in this form it is quite more reactive. When heated with fluorine the result is a mixture of technetium (VI) fluoride.
Technetium metal does dissolve in warm bromine water.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Technetium is insoluble in hydrochloric acid (HCl) and hydrofluoric acid (HF). It does dissolve in nitric acid, HNO3, or concentrated sulphuric acid, H2SO4, both of which are oxidizing, to form solutions of pertechnetic acid, HTcO4. In this form, the technetium is in the formal +7 oxidation state.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Ruthenium does not react with water under normal conditions.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Ruthenium is largely immune to atmospheric attack. On heating with oxygen, ruthenium metal gives ruthenium (IV) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Ruthenium reacts with excess of fluorine to form ruthenium(VI) fluoride.

Heating ruthenium metal at 330°ree;C with chlorine in the presence of carbon monoxide produces dark brown ruthenium(III) chloride, RuCl3; further heating of this product under Cl2 yields a black form of ruthenium(III) chloride.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Rhodium does not react with water under standard conditions.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Rhodium is generally inert in air, when heated with oxygen at 600°ree;C rhodium(III) oxide is produced.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Under anhydrous conditions rhodium will form trihalides with fluorine, chlorine and bromine.
Rhodium reacts directly with fluorine gas to form the highly corrosive rhodium(VI) fluoride.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Rhodium is reknowned for being inert to acids, including aqua regia.

reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Heating palladium metal with oxygen results in formation of palladium(II) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Careful control of the reaction between palladium metal and fluorine gas results in palladium trifluoride.

Palladium(II) chloride is also formed in the controlled reaction of palladium metal and chlorine. Depending upon the reaction conditions, one of two different forms of PdCl2 is formed. In a related reaction palladium(II) bromide, PdBr2, is formed in the reaction of palladium metal and bromine.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Silver will not react with clean water.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Silver is stable in air under normal conditions.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Silver will react with fluorine to form silver(II) difluoride.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Silver dissolves in hot concentrated sulphuric acid and also in nitric acid (dilute or concentrated).

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Cadmium does not react with water.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Cadmium readily burns in air to produce cadmium(II) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Cadmium reacts with fluorine, bromine and iodine to produce cadmium(II) dihalides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Cadmium dissolves slowly in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the Cd(II) ion and hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Cadmium will not dissolve in aqueous alkalis.

reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Unlike gallium (in the same group as indium), indium will not dissolve in aqueous alkali solutions.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: It is stable to water under ambient conditions but on heating with steam, tin reacts with water to from tin dioxide and hydrogen.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: It is stable in air under ambient conditions but on heating in air or oxygen, tin reacts with oxygen to from tin dioxide.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: When red hot antimony will react with water to form antimony(III) trioxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: When heated antimony will react with oxygen in air for form antimony(III) trioxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Antimony reacts under controlled conditions with all of the halogens to form antimony(III) dihalides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Antimony dissolves in hot concentrated sulphuric acid or nitric acid, to form solutions containing Sb(III). The sulphuric acid reaction produces sulphur(IV) dioxide gas. Antimony does not react with hydrochloric acid in the absence of oxygen.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Tellurium does not react with water under normal conditions.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Tellurium burns in air to form dioxide tellurium(IV) oxide
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Under carefully controlled conditions in a sealed tube, tellurium reacts with chlorine to form Te3Cl2.
Tellurium reacts with fluorine and burns to form tellurium(VI) fluoride.

Carefully done, tellurium reacts with fluorine mixed with nitrogen gas at 0°ree;C to form tellurium(IV) fluoride. Tellurium also reacts under controlled conditions with the other halogens chlorine, bromine and iodine to form tetrahalides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Tellurium does not react with dilute non-oxidizing acids.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Tellurium does not react with dilute bases under normal conditions.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Iodine reacts with water to produce hypoiolite, OI-. The pH of the solution determines the position of the equilibrium.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Iodine is not reactive towards with oxygen or nitrogen. However, iodine does react with ozone, O3 to form the unstable yellow I4O9.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Iodine reacts with fluorine at room temperature to form the iodine(V) pentafluoride. At 250°ree;C the same reaction yields iodine(VII) heptafluoride. With careful control of the reaction conditions, (-45°ree;C, suspension of CFCl3), it is posible to isolate the iodine(III) fluoride.
Iodine reacts with bromine to form the very unstable interhalogen species iodine(I) bromide.
Iodine reacts with chlorine at -80°ree;C with excess liquid chlorine to form iodine (III) chloride.
Iodine reacts with chlorine in the presence of water to form iodic acid.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Iodine reacts with hot concentrated nitric acid to form iodic acid. The iodic acid crystallizes out on cooling.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Iodine reacts with hot aqueous alkali to produce iodate, IO3-. Only one sixth of the total iodine is converted in this reaction.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Xenon does not react with water.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Xenon does not react with air.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: At a pressure of 6 atmospheres, xenon and fluorine will react. There are currently no reports of other halogens reacting with xenon.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Xenon does not react with acids.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Xenon does not react with bases.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Cesium metal reacts rapidly with water to form a colourless solution of cesium hydroxide (CsOH) and hydrogen gas. The resulting solution is basic because of the dissolved hydroxide. The reaction is very exothermic. The reaction is so fast that if the reaction is carried out in a glass vessel, the glass container will shatter.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: The surface of cesium soon tarnishes because of reaction with oxygen and moisture from the air. If caesium is burned in air, the result is mainly formation of caesium superoxide, CsO2.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Cesium metal reacts vigorously with all the halogens to form cesium(I) halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Cesium metal dissolves readily in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the aquated Cs(I) ion together with hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Cesium metal reacts rapidly with water to form a colourless basic solution of cesium hydroxide and hydrogen gas. The reaction continues even when the solution becomes basic. The resulting solution is basic because of the dissolved hydroxide. The reaction is very exothermic. The reaction is so fast that if the reaction is carried out in a glass vessel, the glass container will shatter.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Barium reacts readily with water to form barium hydroxide and hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Barium metal is covered with a thin layer of oxide that helps protect the metal from attack by air, but to a lesser extent than the corresponding layer in magnesium. Once ignited, barium metal burns in air to give a mixture of white barium oxide and barium nitride.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Lanthanum is quite electropositive and reacts slowly with cold water and quite quickly with hot water to form lanthanum hydroxide and hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Lanthanum tarnishes slowly in air and burns readily to form lanthanum (III) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Lanthanum metal reacts with all the halogens to form lanthanum(III) halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Lanthanum dissolves readily in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the aquated La(III) ion together with hydrogen gas.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Cerium is quite electropositive and reacts slowly with cold water and quite quickly with hot water to form cerium hydroxide and hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Cerium tarnishes slowly in air and burns readily to form cerium (IV) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Cerium metal reacts with all the halogens to form cerium(III) halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Cerium dissolves readily in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the colourless aquated Ce(III) ion together with hydrogen gas.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Praseodymium is quite electropositive and reacts slowly with cold water and quite quickly with hot water to form praseodymium hydroxide and hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Praseodymium tarnishes slowly in air and burns readily to form a praseodymium oxide which has the approximate formula Pr6O11.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Praseodymium reacts with all the halogens to form praseodymium(III) halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Praseodymium dissolves readily in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the green aquated Pr(III) ion together with hydrogen gas.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Neodymium is quite electropositive and reacts slowly with cold water and quite quickly with hot water to form neodymium hydroxide and hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Neodymium tarnishes slowly in air and burns readily to form neodymium (III) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Neodymium reacts with all the halogens to form neodymium(III) halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Neodymium dissolves readily in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the lilac aquated Nd(III) ion together with hydrogen gas.

reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Promethium dissolves readily in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the pink aquated Pm(III) ion together with hydrogen gas.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Samarium is quite electropositive and reacts slowly with cold water and quite quickly with hot water to form samarium hydroxide and hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Samarium tarnishes slowly in air and burns readily to form samarium (III) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Samarium reacts with all the halogens to form samarium(III) halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Samarium dissolves readily in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the yellow aquated Sm(III) ion together with hydrogen gas.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Europium is quite electropositive and reacts slowly with cold water and fairly quickly with hot water to form europium hydroxide, and hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Europium metal burns readily in air to form europium(III) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Europium metal reacts with all the halogens to form europium(III) halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Europium metal dissolves readily in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the very pale pink Eu(III) ion together with hydrogen gas.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Gadolinium is quite electropositive and reacts slowly with cold water and quite quickly with hot water to form gadolinium hydroxide, Gd(OH)3, and hydrogen gas (H2).
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Gadolinium metal burns readily in air to form Gadolinium(III) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Gadolinium metal reacts with all the halogens to form gadolinium(III) halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Gadolinium metal dissolves readily in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the Gd(III) ion together with hydrogen gas.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Terbium is quite electropositive and reacts slowly with cold water and quite quickly with hot water to form terbium hydroxide and hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Terbium tarnishes slowly in air and burns readily to form a terbium oxide which has the approximate formula.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Terbium reacts with all the halogens to form terbium(III) halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Terbium dissolves readily in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the very pale pink aquated Tb(III) together with hydrogen gas.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Dysprosium is quite electropositive and reacts slowly with cold water and quite quickly with hot water to form dysprosium hydroxide and hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Dysprosium tarnishes slowly in air and burns readily to form dysprosium (III) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Dysprosium reacts with all the halogens to form dysprosium(III) halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Dysprosium dissolves readily in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the yellow aquated Dy(III) ion together with hydrogen gas.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: The silvery white metal holmium is quite electropositive and reacts slowly with cold water and quite quickly with hot water to form holmium hydroxide and hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Holmium metal tarnishes slowly in air and burns readily to form holmium (III) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Holmium metal reacts with all the halogens to form holmium(III) halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Holmium metal dissolves readily in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the yellow aquated Ho(III) ion together with hydrogen gas.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: The erbium is quite electropositive and reacts slowly with cold water and quite quickly with hot water to form erbium hydroxide and hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Erbium tarnishes slowly in air and burns readily to form erbium (III) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Erbium reacts with all the halogens to form erbium(III) halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Erbium dissolves readily in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the yellow aquated Er(III) ion together with hydrogen gas.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: The silvery white metal thulium is quite electropositive and reacts slowly with cold water and quite quickly with hot water to form thulium hydroxide and hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Thulium tarnishes slowly in air and burns readily to form thulium (III) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Thulium reacts with all the halogens to form thulium(III) halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Thulium dissolves readily in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the pale green aquated Tm(III) ion together with hydrogen gas.

reactions.reaction: Reactions with water Ytterbium is quite electropositive and reacts slowly with cold water and quite quickly with hot water to form ytterbium hydroxide and hydrogen gas. 2Yb(s) + 6H2O(g)2Yb(OH)3(aq) + 3H2(g) Reactions with air Ytterbium is quite electropositive and reacts slowly with cold water and quite quickly with hot water to form ytterbium hydroxide and hydrogen gas. 4Yb + 3O22Yb2O3 Reactions with halogens Ytterbium metal reacts with all the halogens to form ytterbium(III) halides. 2Yb(s) + 3F2(g)2YbF3(s) 2Yb(s) + 3Cl2(g)2YbCl3(s) 2Yb(s) + 3Br2(g)2YbBr3(s) 2Yb(s) + 3I2(g)2YbI3(s) Reactions with acids Ytterbium metal dissolves readily in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the colourless aquated Yb(III) ion together with hydrogen gas. 2Yb(s) + 3H2SO4(aq)2Yb3+(aq) + 3SO42-(aq) + 3H2(g)>

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Lutetium is quite electropositive and reacts slowly with cold water and quite quickly with hot water to form lutetium hydroxide and hydrogen gas.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Lutetium metal tarnishes slowly in air and burns readily to form lutetium (III) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Lutetium metal reacts with all the halogens to form lutetium(III) halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Lutetium dissolves readily in dilute sulphuric acid to form solutions containing the colourless aquated Lu(III) ion together with hydrogen gas.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Hafnium does not react with water under normal conditions.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Hafnium is coated with an oxide layer that usually renders it inactive. However hafnium will burn in air if provoked to form hafnium dioxide. Finely divided hafnium is pyrophoric making it a fire hazard.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Hafnium does react with all the halogens upon warming to form hafnium(IV) halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Hafnium is coated with an oxide layer that usually renders it inactive. Most cold mineral acids have little effect. Hafnium does dissolve in hydrofluoric acid.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Hafnium does not appear to react wih alkalis under normal conditions, even when hot.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Tantalum does not react with water under normal conditions. The surface of tantalum metal is protected by a thin oxide layer.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Tantalum does not react with air under normal conditions. The surface of tantalum metal is protected by a thin oxide layer.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Tantalum does react with all of the halogens upon warming to form tantalum(V) halides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Tantalum appear not to be attacked by many acids at room temperature but does dissolve in hydrofluoric acid or oleum (a solution of sulphur trioxide in sulphuric acid also known as fuming sulphuric acid).
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Tantalum metal is attacked by molten alkali.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: At room temperature, tungsten does not react with water.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: At room temperature, tungsten does not react with air or oxygen. At elevated temperatures (red hot), the trioxide tungsten(VI) oxide is formd. Finely divided tungsten metal is pyrophoric.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Tungsten reacts directly with fluorine at room temperature to form tungsten(VI) fluoride.

Tungsten reacts directly with chlorine at 250°ree;C or bromine to form respectively tungsten(VI) chloride or tungsten(VI) bromide. Under carefully controlled conditions, tungsten(V) chloride is formed in the reaction between tungsten metal and chlorine. It seems that tungsten does react to some extent with iodine at red heat.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Tungsten metal is largely unaffected by most acids.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Tungsten metal does not react to any significant extent with dilute solutions of hydroxide.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Rhenium does not react with water under normal conditions.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: As it tarnishes only very slowly in moist air. In practice, however, rhenium is often supplied as a powder or as a sponge, and in this form it is much more reactive. When heated with oxygen the result is rhenium (VII) oxide
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: When heated with fluorine the result is a mixture of rhenium(VI) fluoride and rhenium (VII) fluoride.
If fluorine is burned under pressure at 400°ree;C then then sole product is rhenium heptafluoride.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: In similar fashion to technetium, immediately above rhenium in the periodic table, rhenium is insoluble in hydrochloric acid (HCl) and hydrofluoric acid (HF). It does dissolve in nitric acid, HNO3, or concentrated sulphuric acid, H2SO4, both of which are oxidizing, to form solutions of perrhenic acid, HReO4. In this form, the rhenium is in the formal +7 oxidation state.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Osmium does not react with water under normal conditions.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Osmium is largely immune to atmospheric attack. On heating with oxygen, osmium metal gives the rather volatile (melting point 30°ree;C, boiling point 130°ree;C) osmium(VIII) oxide, OsO4. Finely divided osmium metal gives off a characteristic smell of OsO4, a highly toxic compound.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Osmium reacts with excess of fluorine at 600°ree;C and 400 atmosphere pressure to form osmium(VII) fluoride.
Under milder conditions, the hexafluoride OsF6 is produced.
Osmium reacts with either chlorine or bromine with heating under pressure to form the tetrahalides osmium(IV) chloride or osmium(IV) bromide.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Iridium does not react with water under normal conditions.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Iridium is largely immune to atmospheric attack. On heating with oxygen, iridium metal forms iridium (IV) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Iridium reacts directly with fluorine to form the highly corrosive iridium(VI) fluoride. This material, with care, can be heated to form iridium(V) fluoride, which has the structure [IrF5]4.

The trihalides iridium(III) fluoride, iridium(III) chloride, iridium(III) bromide and iridium(III) iodide can be formed through the direct reaction of the metal with the halogen under anhydrous (dry) conditions.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Iridium metal is notably inert to reaction with acids, including aqua regia (a mixture of hydrochloric acid and nitric acid known for its ability to dissolve gold metal).

reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Platinum metal does not normally react with air or oxygen.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Careful control of the reaction between platinum metal and fluorine gas results in either the volatile platinum(VI) fluoride, PtF6 or the tetrameric platinum(V) fluoride, (PtF5)4. The latter posseses the same type of structure as (IrF5)4, (RhF5)4, (OsF5)4, and (RuF5)4, and disproportionates into platinum(VI) fluoride and platinum(IV) fluoride.
Tetrachloride, tetrabromide and tetraiodide are formed in the reactions of platinum metal and the respective halogens.
Platinum(II) chloride is also formed in the controlled reaction of platinum metal and chlorine. Depending upon the reaction conditions, one of two different forms of PtCl2 is formed.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Gold does not react with water, under any circumstances.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Under normal conditions gold will not react with air.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Gold reacts with chlorine and bromine to form trihalides and with iodine to form a monohalide.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Gold can be dissolved with a mixture of hydrochloric acid (HCl) and concentrated nitric acid (HNO3), in a ration of 3:1. This combination is known as aqua regia, "royal water".
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Gold will not react with aqueous bases.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Mercury does not react with water under normal conditions.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Mercury reacts in air at about 350°ree;C to form mercury(II) oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Mercury metal reacts with fluorine, chlorine, bromine, and iodine to form the mercury(II) dihalides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Mercury does not react with non-oxidizing acids but does react with concentrated nitric acid or concentrated sulphuric acid to form mercury(II) compounds together with nitrogen or sulphur oxides.
Mercury dissolves slowly in dilute nitric acid to form mercury(I) nitrate, mercurous nitrate, Hg2(NO3)2.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Mercury does not react with alkalis under normal conditions.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Thallium tarnishes slowly in moist air or dissolves in water to yield poisonous thallium(I) hydroxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: An oxide layer protects thallium form further reaction with air. When heated strongly in air the poisonous thallium(I) oxide is formed.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Thallium reacts vigorously with fluorine, chlorine and bromine to form poisonous dihalides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Thallium dissolves slowly in sulphuric acid and hydrochloric acid as the product, poisonous thallium(I) salts, are not vey soluble.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: The surface of lead is covered by a thin layer of oxide that means it will not react under normal conditions.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Only upon heating lead to 600-800°ree;C does lead react with oxygen in air to from lead oxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Lead metal reacts vigorously with fluorine at room temperature and chlorine on warming to form poisonous dihalides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: The surface of lead is protected by a thin layer of lead oxide which renders the lead essentially insoluble in sulphuric acid, and so, in the past, a useful container of this acid. Lead reacts slowly with hydrochloric acid and nitric acid. In the latter case, nitrogen oxides are formed together with lead(II) nitrate.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Lead dissolves slowly in cold alkalis to form plumbites.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: When red hot bismuth reacts with water to form bismuth(III) trioxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Upon heating bismuth reacts with oxygen in the air for form bismuth(III) trioxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Bismuth reacts with fluorine to form bismuth(V) fluoride.
Bismuth reacts under controlled conditions with the halogens fluorine, chlorine, bromine and iodine to bismuth(III) trihalides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Bismuth dissolves in concentrated sulphuric acid or nitric acid, to form solutions containing Bi(III). The sulphuric acid reaction produces sulphur(IV) dioxide gas. With hydrochloric acid in the presence of oxygen, bismuth(III) chloride is produced.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Polonium does not react with water.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Polonium burns in air to form polonium(IV) dioxide.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Under controlled conditions polonium will react with chlorine, bromine and iodine to form tetrahalides.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Polonium will dissolve in concentrated hydrochloric acid, sulphuric acid and nitric acid, to form solutions containing Po(II).

reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Astatine reacts with bromine and iodine, both of the by products will dissolve in carbon tetrachloride CCl4.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: Radon does not react with water.
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Radon gas does not react with air.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Radon only reacts with fluorine to form radon(II) fluoride, RnF6 although the exact details of this are unknown.
reaction.title: Reactions with acids
reaction.ptxt: Radon gas does not react with acids.
reaction.title: Reactions with bases
reaction.ptxt: Radon gas does not react with acids.

reaction.title: Reactions
reaction.ptxt: Due to its scarcity and high radioactivity, not much is known about francium reactivity.

reaction.title: Reactions with water
reaction.ptxt: It is thought that reacts very readily with water to form radium hydroxide, Ra(OH)2 and hydrogen gas (H2).
reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: The surface of radium metal is covered with a thin layer of oxide that helps protect the metal from attack by air, but to a lesser extent than the corresponding layer in magnesium.

reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Actinium tarnishes slowly in air and burns easily to form actinium(III) oxide.

reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: When it is exposed to oxygen, thorium slowly tarnishes in air, becoming grey and eventually black.

reaction.title: Reactions
reaction.ptxt: Due to its scarcity, high radioactivity and toxicity, not much is known about protactiniums reactivity.

reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: The most common forms of uranium oxide are triuranium octaoxide (U3O8) and UO2. Both oxide forms are solids that have low solubility in water and are relatively stable over a wide range of environmental conditions. Triuranium octaoxide is (depending on conditions) the most stable compound of uranium and is the form most commonly found in nature. Uranium dioxide is the form in which uranium is most commonly used as a nuclear reactor fuel. At ambient temperatures, UO2 will gradually convert to U3O8. Because of their stability, uranium oxides are generally considered the preferred chemical form for storage or disposal.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: All uranium fluorides are created using uranium tetrafluoride (UF4); UF4 itself is prepared by hydrofluorination of uranium dioxide. Reduction of UF4 with hydrogen at 1000°ree;C produces uranium trifluoride (UF3). Under the right conditions of temperature and pressure, the reaction of solid UF4 with gaseous uranium hexafluoride (UF6) can form the intermediate fluorides of U2F9, U4F17, and UF5.

One method of preparing uranium tetrachloride (UCl4) is to directly combine chlorine with either uranium metal or uranium hydride. The reduction of UCl4 by hydrogen produces uranium trichloride (UCl3) while the higher chlorides of uranium are prepared by reaction with additional chlorine. All uranium chlorides react with water and air.

Bromides and iodides of uranium are formed by direct reaction of, respectively, bromine and iodine with uranium or by adding UH3 to those element's acids. Known examples include: UBr3, UBr4, UI3, and UI4.

reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Neptunium reacts with oxygen to form oxides of the various compositions such as are found in the uranium-oxygen system, including Np3O8 and NpO2.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: Neptunium forms tri- and tetrahalides such as NpF3, NpF4, NpCl4, NpBr3, NpI3.

reaction.title: Reactions with air
reaction.ptxt: Plutonium reacts readily with oxygen, forming PuO and PuO2, as well as intermediate oxides.
reaction.title: Reactions with halogens
reaction.ptxt: It reacts with the halogens, giving rise to compounds such as PuX3 where X can be F, Cl, Br or I; PuF4 and PuF6 are also seen.
reaction.title: Other reactions
reaction.ptxt: It will react with carbon to form PuC, nitrogen to form PuN and silicon to form PuSi2.

reaction.title: Reactions
reaction.ptxt: As only so little americium has ever been made it's reactivity is unknown. It is expected that its behaviour would be similar to that of europium, immediately above americium in the periodic table.

reaction.title: Reactions
reaction.ptxt: As only so little curium has ever been made it's reactivity is unknown. It is expected that its behaviour would be similar to that of gadolinium, immediately above curium in the periodic table.

reaction.title: Reactions
reaction.ptxt: As only so little lawrencium has ever been made it's reactivity is unknown. It is expected that its behaviour would be similar to that of lutetium, immediately above it in the periodic table, and yttrium (two places above it).

reaction.ptxt: As only so little rutherfordium has ever been made it's reactivity is unknown. It is expected that its behaviour would be similar to that of hafnium, immediately above it in the periodic table, and zirconium (two places above it).
